messageBody:
Hi Ken,

Thanks for these hints. I have managed to write my own test runner that
used constructor dependency injection and can run junit 4 tests.
It's not production level code at the moment but this does not
matter -I just need it for a research prototype for a paper I am working
on. I have also created a google code project, the actual code and a
more comprehensive explanation what the project is all about can be
found there: http://code.google.com/p/treaty/
<http://code.google.com/p/treaty/> .

My feeling is that this (runtime testing of discovered services) is an
important use case and as frameworks that use late binding such as
Spring and Eclipse are gaining momentum, there will be increasing demand
for runtime verification. Whenever I coded Eclipse plugins in the past I
always found that having test cases attached to the extension points (at
least if the x point provides interfaces to be implemented by the
extensions) would have made the plugins much better Â–Eclipse could
run in a "safe mode" where test cases are executed whenever a
plugin extending the respective extension point is loaded. That would
also make it possible to use this kind of design in applications that
require high reliability.

The nice thing about test cases (for me at least) is that they can be
used to define the semantics of methods in a sense that they exclude
implementations with unintended behaviour and therefore describe the
intended model. I see them very much on the same level as interfaces,
and not implementation classes.

Cheers,Jens


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Kent Beck" <kentb@...> wrote:
>
> Jens,
>
> I think I understand your situation. What makes it a challenge for
JUnit 4
> is that the new architecture is a DSL and the binding is intended to
happen
> at compile time. I wonder if a JUnit 3.8-style test would be easier.
Here is
> pseudo-code for what I'm thinking:
>
> public void testDiscoveredList(Class klass) {
> TestSuite suite= new TestSuite(ListTest.class);
> for (Test each : suite.tests) { // Does this work for Enumeration?
> ListTest test= (ListTest) each; // Sorry about the downcast...
> each.setList(createList(klass));
> }
> junit.framework.TestResult result= new
junit.framework.TestResult();
> suite.run(result);
> ...check results and act appropriately
> }
>
> On a larger scale, what is interesting to me about this example is the
way
> the shift to a DSL encouraged earlier binding and the resulting loss
of
> important (to you) flexibility.
>
> I'm sure you could accomplish the above with the JUnit 4 model, but
you'd
> have to circumvent more of it. We're trying to address this with the
changes
> in 4.5, but I'm not sure it would easily accomodate your scenario even
so.
> I'd love to see a custom runner to prove me wrong, though.
>
> Take care,
>
> Kent Beck
> Three Rivers Institute

>
> What I am trying to avoid are explicit references to implementation
> classes in test cases, like in
> assertAddingAnElementIncreasesTheSizeByOne(new ArrayList());.
>
> The background of my question is the following: I want to use tests in
> a scenario where interfaces describe services (like in OSGI). When a
> service becomes available (a class implementing the interface), I want
> to run all tests for this service at runtime (!) to verify that the
> service has the correct behaviour. I cannot do this at build time as
> the service is discovered dynamically and I don't own the
> implementation. So I somehow have to inject the service implementation
> into the test case before setUp is executed.
>
> Jens
